questions.question: A customer complains about a feature that your team spent months developing. What is the best response according to Customer Obsession?
options: Explain to the customer why the feature is actually good
Listen to understand their concern and work backwards from their needs
Ignore the complaint since most customers are happy
Ask your manager to handle the difficult customer

questions.question: A competitor launches a feature that customers love. What should you do?
options: Ignore it and focus on your own roadmap
Copy the feature exactly as they built it
Be inspired by it and think how you can improve your customer experience

questions.question: You're deciding whether to add customer reviews to your product pages. Publishers object because some reviews might be negative. What should you do?
options: Remove reviews to keep publishers happy
Add honest reviews because they help customers make better decisions
Let publishers write the reviews themselves

questions.question: During an economic downturn, how should you approach customer relationships according to Customer Obsession?
options: Extract maximum revenue from customers while you can
Proactively help customers optimize costs so they can succeed long-term
Reduce customer support to save money
Focus only on acquiring new customers

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'working backwards' document at Amazon?
options: To document code after it's written
To ensure the product will matter for customers before writing any code
To assign blame when projects fail

questions.question: Being customer obsessed means you should never consider:
options: Neither - both should be considered while focusing on customers

questions.question: You notice a problem in a system that isn't your responsibility. What should you do?
options: Ignore it - it's not your job
Send a vague email mentioning the issue
Find the owner or take care of it yourself if there's no owner
Wait for someone else to notice

questions.question: What is the difference between a 'renter' and an 'owner' mindset?
options: Owners think about long-term consequences; renters don't care about damage
Owners only focus on their specific tasks

questions.question: A colleague says 'I don't get paid more if I come up with ideas to increase revenue, so why bother?' This demonstrates:
What does 'never say that's not my job' mean in practice?
options: Do everyone else's work for them
Ensure problems are owned and have a path to resolution
Never set boundaries on your role

questions.question: When facing a hard problem, what should an owner do?
options: Punt it to someone else with more experience
Wait for management to assign someone
Pull together the right people to find the solution
Document why it's impossible to solve

questions.question: Owners should always ask themselves:
options: What would get me promoted fastest?
What would I do if this were my personal money?
How can I minimize my workload?
Who else could do this instead of me?

questions.question: What often happens to companies that rely only on their original innovative idea?
options: They struggle to sustain success in a dynamic world

questions.question: Amazon's marketplace initially failed as an 'auctions' website similar to eBay. What does this teach about innovation?
options: Give up after the first failure
Keep iterating until you find the right simplifying solution

questions.question: What was the 'simplifying assumption' that made Amazon's marketplace successful?
options: Create a separate website for third-party sellers
Put third-party products on the same pages as first-party products

questions.question: What does 'not invented here' syndrome refer to?
options: Refusing to consider good ideas from external sources
Both A and B represent this syndrome

questions.question: According to Invent and Simplify, being 'misunderstood for long periods of time' is:
options: Acceptable when doing truly new things

questions.question: What is an example of 'whole cloth invention' at Amazon?
What is a common misinterpretation of 'Are Right, A Lot'?
options: It means my idea should always win in debates
It involves questioning your own beliefs

questions.question: In meetings with your team, when should leaders typically speak?
options: Last, to hear everyone's input first

questions.question: What does 'seeking to disconfirm your beliefs' mean?
options: Actively questioning your closely held opinions to find better answers

questions.question: The goal of being 'Right, A Lot' is ultimately about:
options: Being the smartest person in the room
Getting to the best possible answer for customers

questions.question: In the best meetings, what sometimes happens regarding the leader's opinion?
options: The leader always shares their opinion first
The leader may never need to express an opinion because the team sorted it out

questions.question: Amazon operates in 'high areas of ambiguity.' What skill is essential for leaders in this environment?
options: Sifting through noise to find the signal that matters for customers

questions.question: According to Learn and Be Curious, what happens at the moment you think there's little left to learn?
options: You are unwinding as an individual and professional

questions.question: What differentiates people who grow substantially in their careers from those who stagnate?
options: Their willingness to keep learning and being curious

questions.question: When your expertise in an area 'flips upside down' due to change, the right mindset is to:
options: Feel threatened and resist the change
View it as part of the fun and embrace learning anew
Ignore the changes and stick to what you know

questions.question: What's the difference between talking about learning and actually learning?
options: Talking about learning is more important
You must build a real plan to change AND actually make that change

questions.question: The goal should be to get better:
options: Even a little bit better every single day

questions.question: Self-assessment and self-awareness are critical for:
options: Identifying what you do well and what you need to improve

questions.question: When should you lower the hiring bar?
options: When there's time pressure on a project
When the role is considered less important
Never - who we hire is one of the most important decisions

questions.question: In Amazon's hiring loops, each interviewer focuses on:
Being a manager is described as:
options: A privilege with responsibility to develop your team

questions.question: Which managers have the biggest positive impact on careers?
options: Those who identify both strengths AND growth areas

questions.question: What mistake have many companies made recently regarding feedback?
options: Not telling people what they're great at
Finding it harder to give critical feedback about growth areas

questions.question: 'Raise the bar' in hiring means:
options: Every new hire should be as good as the average
Every new hire should make the team better than before
Only hire people exactly like existing employees

questions.question: Amazon's standards are described as:
Why is setting high standards described as 'highly leveraged'?
options: People in meetings you're in can take those standards to meetings you can't attend
It eliminates the need for training

questions.question: During the pandemic, what happened to standards at many companies?
options: They had to be relaxed, and now companies are fighting to get back to high standards

questions.question: What leads to better results according to this principle?
Why is it essential to maintain high standards in today's age?
options: It's easy for customers to switch, and the internet gives them good information

questions.question: Leaders should ensure that:
options: Defects are acceptable if caught later
Defects don't get sent down the line and problems stay fixed

questions.question: 'Thinking small is a self-fulfilling prophecy' means:
options: Small goals are easier to achieve
If you think small, you'll only achieve small things

questions.question: What does 'looking around corners' mean?
options: Being physically aware of your surroundings
Anticipating future customer needs and technology changes

questions.question: Amazon's progression from multi-day delivery to same-day to potentially drone delivery (hours) demonstrates:
options: Thinking big and constantly raising the bar

questions.question: If you want to build a company that lasts over 100 years, you:
options: Run the same playbook for decades
Cannot run the same playbook for decades - you must change and take risks

questions.question: Bold initiatives like reinventing healthcare require:
options: Thinking big and accepting they're not simple to do
Waiting for someone else to try first

questions.question: Leaders who think big should:
options: Create and communicate a bold direction that inspires results
Wait until the bold idea is fully proven
Only share ideas with senior leadership

questions.question: Speed matters in business:
options: At every stage, in every industry, at every size (except monopolies)

questions.question: What is a 'two-way door' decision?
options: A decision that requires extensive study
A decision that can be easily reversed if wrong
A decision that can never be changed
A decision that requires CEO approval

questions.question: Most decisions at Amazon are:
options: One-way door decisions requiring careful analysis
Two-way door decisions that should be made quickly

questions.question: The concept of 'closing windows' means:
options: Opportunities are time-limited and competitors are racing for them too

questions.question: Is speed preordained by company size or culture?
options: Yes, large companies can't be fast
Yes, certain industries are inherently slow
No, speed is a leadership and culture decision
Yes, compliance concerns always slow things down

questions.question: Is there tension between 'highest standards' and 'bias for action'?
options: Yes, but you can be fast while still having high standards
Yes, and you must always choose one over the other

questions.question: Amazon should think of itself as:
options: A company too big to move fast

questions.question: Amazon has 'door desks' as a signal that:
options: The company wants to be scrappy and avoid extra garnishing

questions.question: 'Constraints breed resourcefulness' means:
AWS's S3 and EC2 were built with teams of:
When someone says 'It's only $100 million,' this represents:
options: Being numb to numbers - a dangerous mindset

questions.question: How should savings from frugality be used?
options: Given back to customers as lower prices and more capabilities

questions.question: The best way to build your career is:
options: To build amazing experiences as leanly as possible

questions.question: 'There are no extra points for' what, according to Frugality?
options: Growing headcount, budget size, or fixed expense

questions.question: Earn Trust does NOT mean:
options: Avoiding challenges to maintain social harmony
Delivering what you said you would

questions.question: 'Leaders do not believe their own body odor smells of perfume' means:
options: Leaders should be self-aware and self-critical, not blind to their own faults

questions.question: If something you own isn't going well, you should:
options: Hide it until you fix it
Own it, say it's not going well, be self-critical, and fix it

questions.question: Using data and benchmarking is important because:
options: It shows whether you're actually as good as you claim

questions.question: In the story about the presentation with wrong numbers, what was the valuable lesson?
options: Dive deep and have ownership over your details

questions.question: Challenging someone respectfully in a meeting is:
options: Part of earning trust through honest discourse

questions.question: Is there tension between Think Big (strategic) and Dive Deep (details)?
options: Yes, but Amazon expects leaders to be great at BOTH
Yes, so you must choose one
No, details don't matter if strategy is right

questions.question: Why is the narrative format useful compared to PowerPoint?
options: It's harder to fake the details in a narrative

questions.question: When metrics look good but you hear a customer anecdote about a problem, you should:
options: Ignore the anecdote - metrics are truth
Follow the anecdote because problems may not show in broad metrics at scale

questions.question: At Amazon's scale, even a 0.5% impact affects:
'No task is beneath' a leader means:
options: Leaders should only do strategic work
Leaders should be willing to do any task needed to get things right

questions.question: Good leaders find mechanisms to:
At Amazon, speaking up when you think something is wrong is:
options: Expected from everyone regardless of level

questions.question: 'I told you so' is useless at Amazon because:
options: It means you either didn't speak up when you should have, or you're not fully committing

questions.question: Social cohesion (compromising to get along) is:
options: Something to avoid - truth-seeking is more important

questions.question: If two people disagree (one says ceiling is 10ft, other says 14ft), compromise to 12ft is:
options: Usually wrong - there's a truth that's closer to one answer
How all disagreements should be resolved

questions.question: After a decision is made and you were on the losing side, you should:
options: Commit wholly to the decision even though you disagreed
Wait for the decision to fail to prove you were right

questions.question: Why is full commitment after disagreement important?
options: Because businesses need to move and can't be stagnant with ongoing debates

questions.question: Why is Deliver Results positioned as the final, crucial principle?
options: Because if you fail on delivery, nothing else matters

questions.question: What's the difference between outputs and inputs?
options: Outputs are high-level results; inputs are the initiatives that drive those results

questions.question: Can you actively affect outputs by watching them on a monitor?
options: No, you manage inputs which then affect outputs
Monitoring is the most important activity

questions.question: Launch (delivery) is described as:
options: The starting line - where you can now build something meaningful

questions.question: How do successful products typically develop at Amazon?
options: They're breakaway hits on first launch
They require 7-8 iterations before becoming meaningful
They succeed immediately or are killed

questions.question: The best teams are characterized by:
options: Fast and organized launching, then constant iteration

sections.section: Strive to be Earth's Best Employer

questions.question: What makes a company a great place to work according to this principle?
options: Meaningful mission, scale, invention, smart colleagues, and long-term commitment

questions.question: Leaders should ask themselves about their employees:
options: Are they growing? Are they empowered? Are they ready for what's next?
Only 'are they loyal to the company?'

questions.question: Leaders must have a vision for employees' personal success:
options: Whether that success is at Amazon or elsewhere

questions.question: Can Amazon do everything every employee wants?
options: Yes, being Earth's best employer means doing everything
No, the company can't be all things to everyone

questions.question: Which is NOT mentioned as an inspiring aspect of working at Amazon?
options: Making customers' lives easier at large scale

questions.question: Areas for continued improvement include:
options: Safety, manager training, diversity and inclusion

sections.section: Success and Scale Bring Broad Responsibility

questions.question: The key question Amazon must constantly ask is:
options: Are the communities where we operate better off because we're there?
How can we reduce costs further?

questions.question: Amazon's contribution to communities includes:
options: Jobs plus affordable housing, food security, education, and disaster relief

questions.question: Amazon's unique approach to homelessness includes:
options: Housing families overnight in corporate buildings (Mary's Place partnership)

questions.question: 'Leaders create more than they consume' means:
options: Leaving things better than how you found them

questions.question: Why did Amazon wait to be more involved in communities?
options: They waited until they were profitable to have sustainable impact

questions.question: 'We must be humble and thoughtful about even secondary effects of our actions' reflects:
options: Recognizing that being big means broader responsibility for impact
